Arg.V:
#!/bin/bash
function updatepk() { if [ ! -z $1 ]; then if [ -e /var/run/yum.pid ];then exit 10 fi result=`yum -y update $1 2>&1` status=$? commandexist=`echo $result | grep -E "yum: command not found"` if [ "$commandexist" != "" ]; then exit 8 fi
commandexist=`echo $result | grep -E "yum: No such file or directory"` if [ "$commandexist" != "" ]; then exit 8 fi
islock=`echo $result | grep -E "lock /var/run/yum.pid"`
if [ "$islock" != "" ]; then exit 10 fi
islock=`echo $result | grep -E "/var/run/yum.pid: another copy is running"`
if [ "$islock" != "" ]; then exit 10 fi
isnotconnected=`echo $result | grep -E "There was an error communicating with RHN"` if [ "$isnotconnected" != "" ]; then exit 9 fi
isnotconnected=`echo $result | grep -E "This system is not registered with RHN"` if [ "$isnotconnected" != "" ]; then exit 9 fi
isnotconnected=`echo $result | grep -E "No Repositories Available to Set Up"` if [ "$isnotconnected" != "" ]; then exit 9 fi isnotconnected=`echo $result | grep -E "Error Class Code: 9 Error Class Info: Invalid System Credentials"` if [ "$isnotconnected" != "" ]; then exit 9 fi isscriptletfailed=`echo $result | grep -E "error:" | grep -E "scriptlet failed, exit status 255"` if [ "$isscriptletfailed" != "" ]; then exit 6 fi if [ $status -ne 0 ];then exit 7 fi fi } updatepk scl-utils
exit 0

exit 0

Vulnerability.Title: scl-utils bug fix and enhancement update
Vulnerability.Description: The scl-utils packages provide a runtime utility and RPM packaging macros for packaging Software Collections. Software Collections allow users to concurrently install multiple versions of the same RPM packages on the system. Using the scl utility, users may enable specific versions of RPMs, which are installed into the /opt directory. This update fixes the following bugs: In previous versions of scl-utils, the working directory was changed during package builds, which caused complications to package maintainers. These complications ranged from mild inconveniences to build failures if the code in the spec file worked with the working directory. This bug has been fixed, and the working directory no longer changes during the build time. (BZ#1029515) This update introduces a new way to call the "scl enable" command. The scl utility now supports the double dash as a separator between collections and the command; using the separator makes calling the command more convenient. (BZ#1029517) When building SCL noarch metapackages on a 64-bit machine, the build failed with an error message. To fix this bug, the "%ifarch" conditionals have been changed, and affected packages are now built correctly (BZ#1029516) Previously, it was impossible to specify runtime dependencies between collections. For example, if one collection depended on another, the user had to enable both of them manually. This update introduces a feature in which a collection has a way to enable another collection implicitly during startup. (BZ#874417) Previously, scl-utils did not respect the "%define debug_package %{nil}" line in the ~/.rpmmacros file, which instructs a package not to place debugging information into a separate "debuginfo" package whenever a package is built. With this update, the rpm macros get no longer overwritten, and the user can now disable the stripping of binaries and libs and disable generation of a debuginfo subpackage using "%define debug_package %{nil}" in a rpm spec file. (BZ#1071834) Previously, the *-runtime package of every Software Collection owned a number of directories including the /opt/rh/*/root/usr/lib recursive directory. However, the /rpm/javadoc.req file was owned by other packages as well. With this update, javadoc.req belongs to -collection1-scldevel, and *-runtime only owns the containing directory, thus fixing the bug. (BZ#1133831) In addition, this update adds the following enhancement: Support for SCLs exported over NFS has been improved by allowing the "scl register" command. Now, when a directory with a Software Collection is mounted using NFS, by running "scl register" the user informs scl-utils about this directory, and scl-utils stores this information in the /etc/scl/ directory. (BZ#1099394) Users of scl-utils are advised to upgrade to these updated packages, which fix these bugs and add this enhancement. Note for remediation: Please disable the SELinux for RHEL 4/5 when repairing, or some rpm packages will fail to install.
